lesson.name: Lesson 2: Motion in a Straight Line

page.title: Reflect before you start
page.contents:
This lesson is called Motion in a Straight Line.  It will cover:

  • Different ways to represent real-life motions.
  • Some quantities which we use to mathematically describe motion (position, displacement, distance travelled, speed, velocity)
  • The vector nature of position, displacement, and velocity
  • Relative velocity

Before you start to look at any complicated content, whether it is a textbook, a set of video lectures, a web page, whatever, it is a good idea to prepare to learn by doing a bit of reflection.  To develop the habit it is good to write some reflections.  In the space below write three things (sentences, point form, whatever you want) about what you are about to learn.  Here are some things you might write about below:

  • List things that you think you might learn about in the lesson (in more detail than was given in the list above).
  • List things that you already know about the topics of this lesson.
  • List things that you have heard about these topics, but don't understand.

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Main page - choose lesson part here
page.contents:
You do not have to finish the lesson all in one sitting.  You may reattempt it if you are not satisfied with how you did.  Here is a "map" of the lesson.  This is partly because moodle has a tendency (which I haven't figured out) to skip the Reflective Writing parts of these lessons.  This map will help you see if you have missed any and find your way to where they should be.

Choose one of the following lesson parts.  When you have finished that part of the lesson you will be brought back to this page.  When you have finished all parts of the lesson click the "OK, I'm done" button to end the lesson.

page.title: Motion diagram - turning around
page.contents:
Here is a motion diagram:

Which of the descriptions below best describes the motion shown in this diagram?

answer.answer_text: The object moves to the left while slowing down. It stops, then moves to the right while speeding up.
answer.response: Yes, it stops at point 5.

answer.answer_text: The object moves to the left. Then it stops. Then it moves slightly down. Then it moves back to the right.
answer.response: No. Notice the "same point" label on the duplicates of point 5. This means that the points after point 5 have been slightly displaced so that they don't fall on top of the points before point 5.

answer.answer_text: Two objects are moving. One is going left while slowing down. The other is moving right while speeding up.
answer.response: No, this is a motion diagram for a single object. Notice the "same point" label on the duplicates of point 5. This means that the points after point 5 have been slightly displaced so that they don't fall on top of the points before point 5.

answer.answer_text: The object moves left, then it moves to the right.
answer.response: Yes, but you need to give more detail. Simply saying the direction of a motion is never sufficient. A complete description of a motion always includes information about how the velocity is changing.

answer.answer_text: The object moves to the left speeding up. Then it stops. Then it moves to the right speeding up.
answer.response: No, it is not speeding up as it moves to the left.

page.title: How to draw turning around
page.contents: You seem to have missed the part of the lecture where we saw how to draw motion diagrams of objects which reverse direction.  The problem here is that the points for the "trip back" fall on top of or between the points for the "trip forwards".  This leads to a very confusing motion diagram.  So we slightly displace the "trip back" part of the motion diagram so that it appears along side of the "trip forwards" part.

answer.answer_text: Got it. Try another question like this.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: End of branch
page.contents: End of branch

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: How to recognize speeding up/slowing down
page.contents:
You seem to have missed the part of the lecture where we saw how to tell whether an object is speeding up or slowing down by looking at its motion diagram.  Remember that the points in a motion diagram are drawn at equal time intervals.  If an object is moving quickly then it will go a long distance during a set time interval while a slower object will go a smaller distance in the same time interval.  So when later points in the diagram are farther apart than earlier points this means the object is speeding up.  When later points are closer together this means the object is slowing down.

For example:

At this stage it is best to not try to assign positive/negative to directions.  Just work using intuitive descriptions (up/down/right/left/east/west etc.) of directions.

answer.answer_text: Got it. Try another question like this.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Const. speed then speed up
page.contents:
Here is a motion diagram:

Which description below is the best match for this motion diagram?

answer.answer_text: The object moves to the right. It goes at a constant speed for a while, then speeds up.
answer.response: Yes. It appears to start speeding up sometime just after time 4.

answer.answer_text: The object moves to the right, speeding up.
answer.response: Almost, but it isn't speeding up for the whole time.

answer.answer_text: The object moves to the right at constant speed.
answer.response: Almost, but it isn't going at a constant speed for the whole time.

answer.answer_text: The object moves to the right and accelerates to the right.
answer.response: It isn't accelerating for the whole time. Also, for now it is best to just talk about how the speed changes (speeding up/slowing down) instead of trying to talk about the direction of the acceleration.

answer.answer_text: The object moves to the right. It slows down for a while, then speeds up.
answer.response: No, this object is not slowing down at any time.

page.title: Ball thrown upwards
page.contents: Here is a motion diagram: Which of the descriptions below best describes the motion shown in this diagram?

answer.answer_text: An object moves upward while slowing down. Then it moves down while speeding up.
answer.response: Yes. The direction of motion reverses at time 4. This motion is very much like a real object that is thrown straight upward.

answer.answer_text: An object moves up, then it moves down.
answer.response: Yes, but it isn't sufficient to just give the direction of motion. You also need to describe how the speed changes during the motion.

answer.answer_text: An object moves up. Then it moves slightly left. Then it moves down.
answer.response: No. Notice the "same point" label on the duplicates of point 4. This means that the points after point 4 have been slightly displaced so that they don't fall on top of the points before point 4.

answer.answer_text: Two objects are moving. One is going up while slowing down. The other is moving down while speeding up.
answer.response: No, this is a motion diagram for a single object. Notice the "same point" label on the duplicates of point 4. This means that the points after point 4 have been slightly displaced so that they don't fall on top of the points before point 4.

answer.answer_text: An object moves upward while speeding up. Then it moves down while speeding up.
answer.response: No. It is not speeding up when it is moving upward.

page.title: Lecture 2-2: Position, Displacement and Speed (Part 1)
page.contents: Watch this online lecture.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Calculate displacement
page.contents:
Over some time interval, the initial and final position of some object are:

\( \vec{r}_i = 5 \hat{i} -2 \hat{j} \, \textrm{m} \),

\( \vec{r}_f = -3 \hat{i} -3 \hat{j} \, \textrm{m} \).

What is the object’s displacement over this time interval?

answer.response: Yes.
No.  It looks like you added the initial and final positions.  That isn't a displacement.
No.  You must have reversed the order in the subtraction.  Remember, a change is always a *final minus initial*.
No.  You were asked for a displacement, which is a vector.  The answer you have selected is not a vector and so it can't be a displacement.

page.title: Lecture 2-2: Position, Displacement and Speed (Part 2)
page.contents: Watch this video lecture.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: get displacement - 1
page.contents:
Olaf the snowman is running down the hill towards a fire which he is curious about.  He starts 4 m uphill from the fire and runs to it.  He then trickles down the hill a further 6 m before stopping.  Someone has conveniently left a set of axes lying around as shown in the diagram.  Olaf's initial and final locations are shown.

What is Olaf's x-component of displacement from his starting point to the place where he stops?

answer.response: Yup.

The axes set a sign convention which you haven't used. Or recall that a displacement is
$$\Delta x = x_f - x_i$$

No, that's his final position, which is different from his displacement. Remember that displacement is
$$\Delta x = x_f - x_i$$

No, that's his distance from the origin at the end of his motion. First of all, pay attention to the sign convention that the definition of the axes defines. Secondly remember that displacement is
$$\Delta x = x_f - x_i$$

answer.answer_text: We can't calculate his displacement. We need to know what angle the hillside makes with the horizontal.
answer.response: No. We are only looking for the x-component of displacement and the entire motion is parallel to the x-axis. So no angles enter into this.

page.title: v_x from graph
page.contents: An x vs. t graph is shown above for some object.  At t = 1 s, what is the x-component of the velocity of this object?

answer.response: Yes.
Look at the graph.  Isn't the slope negative?
No.  Did you do x/t instead of \( \Delta x/ \Delta t \)?  The velocity component is the *slope* of the x vs. t graph.
No.  Did you do x/t instead of \( \Delta x/ \Delta t \) (and then flip the sign because you saw that it must be negative)?  The velocity component is the *slope* of the x vs. t graph.
No.  Why zero?  I'm not sure what misconception would lead you to this.  You want the slope of the graph...

page.title: Reflect on what you have learned
page.contents:
Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1104 - Response to Unit 2 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper.  Don't put your name on it; I would rather mark "blind".  Write a big heading saying "First Half".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. Can displacement be negative?  Can the x-component of displacement be negative?  If either or both of these can be negative then describe the circumstances under which it is negative.

You will add more to this sheet after one of the other lectures in this unit.  You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Ball thrown downward (bounce)
page.contents: Here is a motion diagram: Which of the descriptions below best describes the motion shown in this diagram?

answer.answer_text: An object moves down while speeding up. It reverses direction and then moves up while slowing down.
answer.response: Yes. This is very much like the behaviour of a ball which is dropped and bounces off of the floor.

answer.answer_text: An object moves down while slowing down. It stops and then moves up while speeding up.
answer.response: You have the reversal of direction correct, but you haven't correctly seen when it speeding up and when it is slowing down.

answer.answer_text: The object moves down. Then it moves slightly to the right. Then it moves up.
answer.response: No. Notice the "same point" label on the duplicates of point 4. This means that the points after point 4 have been slightly displaced so that they don't fall on top of the points before point 4.

answer.answer_text: Two objects are moving. One is going down while speeding up. The other is moving up while slowing down.
answer.response: No, this is a motion diagram for a single object. Notice the "same point" label on the duplicates of point 4. This means that the points after point 4 have been slightly displaced so that they don't fall on top of the points before point 4.

answer.answer_text: Two objects are moving. One is going down while slowing down. The other is moving up while speeding up.
answer.response: No, this is a motion diagram for a single object. Notice the "same point" label on the duplicates of point 4. This means that the points after point 4 have been slightly displaced so that they don't fall on top of the points before point 4. Also, you haven't correctly seen when it is speeding up or slowing down.

page.title: Motion diagram - speed up then slow down
page.contents:
Here is a motion diagram:

Which description below is the best match for this motion diagram?

answer.answer_text: An object moves diagonally up and to the right. It speeds up for a while and then slows down for a while.
answer.response: Yes. Maximum speed seems to be sometime between time 3 and time 4.

answer.answer_text: An object moves diagonally up and to the right.
answer.response: Yes, but it is not sufficient to just say what direction the object moves in. You also need to describe how its speed changes.

answer.answer_text: The object moves in the positive direction. It is accelerating in the positive direction.
answer.response: No. First of all, the object is not accelerating in the same direction for the whole time shown. Secondly, we haven't defined "positive" and "negative". As much as possible work with intuitive descriptions of directions (up/down/left/right/north/etc.). You do need to be able to turn these into mathematical descriptions such as positive and negative, but don't do this before you have to.

answer.answer_text: The object moves diagonally up and to the right while slowing down.
answer.response: Almost, but the object is not slowing down for the whole time shown.

answer.answer_text: The object moves diagonally up and to the right while speeding up.
answer.response: Almost, but the object is not speeding up for the whole time shown.

page.title: Rick and Morty, different axes
page.contents:
Rick and Morty notice that their spaceship is flying away without them!  (“Dammit!  Did you leave the key in the ignition, Morty?”)  They each measure the spaceship’s velocity, but they use different coordinate systems, as shown.  Morty measures the velocity to be

$$-25 \hat{i} + 10 \hat{j} \, \textrm{m/s}$$

What velocity does Rick measure?

answer.response: Yes.
No.  Notice that Rick's y-axis points in the same direction as Morty's does.
No.  Notice that Rick's x-axis points the opposite way to Morty's.
No.  Notice that Rick's x-axis points the opposite way to Morty's and Rick's y-axis points the same way as Morty's.

page.title: Lecture 2-4: Changing Velocity (Part 2)
page.contents: Watch this video lecture.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Average or instantaneous velocity
page.contents: Which is greater, the average y-component of velocity from t4 to t9 or the instantaneous y-component of velocity at t4?

answer.response: Yes.
No.  Look at slopes.  The line connecting the points at t_4 and t_9 gives us an average velocity and the tangent to the curve at t_4 gives the instantaneous velocity.
No.  Look at slopes.  The line connecting the points at t_4 and t_9 gives us an average velocity and the tangent to the curve at t_4 gives the instantaneous velocity.
No.  The previous lecture has been talking about how to determine velocity components from graphs.  Look back at it.

page.title: Get average velocity component
page.contents: The table of data and graph shown above are for a falling ball.  What is the ball’s average y-component of velocity from t = 0.1 s to t = 0.6 s?

answer.response: Yes.
No.  Did you take 3.1 m / 0.6 s?  So you did y/t.  But that isn't an average velocity component.  The average velocity component is the slope, \( \Delta y / \Delta t \).
No, that is y (with wrong units?).  We want \( v_y \).
Did you take 3.1 m/ 0.5 s.  So you did \( y / \Delta t \).  But the velocity component should be \( \Delta y/\Delta t \)

page.contents: Watch this video lecture.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Find final position of air puck
page.contents:
An air puck is moving at a constant velocity

$$\vec{v} = \hat{i} - 2\hat{j} \, \textrm{m/s}$$

At t = 2 s it passes through the position

$$\vec{r}_i = 2\hat{i} + 7\hat{j} \, \textrm{m}$$

Where is it at t = 5 s?

answer.response: Yes.

No.  I think you are not paying attention to the difference between t and \(\Delta t \).  We are looking for the position 3 s after the initial time.  You have found the position 5 s after the initial time.
No.  That is the displacement, not the final position.

Did you take \( \vec{r}_i \) and multiply it by 5?  That's not how to get the final position.  We have obtained a relationship between the initial position, final position, velocity, and time interval.  You should use that relationship.

page.title: get velocity from graph
page.contents: Below is the x-component of position vs. time graph for some object.  What is the x-component of velocity of this object?

answer.response: Yes, it is just the slope of the line.
No. You used v=x/t instead of $$v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}
Oops! I think you missed that the t-axis was scaled so each "tick" was an increment of 2 s.
I think you either misread the graph or tried to find the slope with run/rise instead of rise/run.

answer.answer_text: We need to know what time or range of times we are finding the velocity at in order to answer this.
answer.response: No. Notice that the graph is a straight line. So this object is moving at constant velocity. The average velocity between any two points is the same as the instantaneous velocity at any point.

page.title: Convert velocity to component form
page.contents:
An airplane flies at an angle to the x-axis as shown.

The velocity of the airplane is \( \vec{v} = \) (200 m/s, 60°).  Which of the following is the airplane's velocity in component form?

answer.response: No.  Did you draw the triangle before attempting to decompose the vector into its components?  Don't try to do trigonometry without drawing the triangle.
Does this make sense?  Based on the direction that the velocity vector is pointing, shouldn't both of its components be positive?  Check your calculator.  Is it in radian mode?

Does this make sense?  Based on the direction that the velocity vector is pointing, shouldn't both of its components be positive?  Check your calculator.  Is it in radian mode?  Also, draw the triangle before trying to do trigonometry.  You may have mixed up the components.

page.title: Motion diagram - going up
page.contents: Here is a motion diagram:                  Which description below is the best match for this motion diagram?

answer.answer_text: The object moves up at constant speed for a while, then slows down and stops.
answer.response: Yes, it looks like it is going at constant speed up until point 4, then it slows down after that.

answer.answer_text: The object moves in the positive direction, accelerating in the negative direction.
answer.response: No. First of all, the object is not accelerating for the whole time shown. Secondly, we haven't defined "positive" and "negative". As much as possible work with intuitive descriptions of directions (up/down/left/right/north/etc.). You do need to be able to turn these into mathematical descriptions such as positive and negative, but don't do this before you have to.

answer.answer_text: The object moves up, accelerating down.
answer.response: Almost, but the object is not accelerating for the whole time shown.

answer.answer_text: The object moves upward while slowing down.
answer.response: Almost, but it its not slowing down during the whole time shown.

answer.answer_text: The object moves upward while accelerating upward.
answer.response: No. For now it is best to just describe whether the object is speeding up or slowing down rather than trying to decide on the direction of the acceleration.

page.title: Match relative velocities
page.contents:
Olaf just can't wait to give the Human Torch a big hug!  He is riding on Cart A which going at (5 m/s, right).  The Human Torch is riding Cart B which is going at (3 m/s, right).  You are sitting stationary on the ground nearby.  Sam is riding by on his super-modern bike with a velocity of (2 m/s, left).

Match each object with the velocity as measured by Sam.

answer.answer_text: Yes, you have to subtract the velocity of the observer to get the velocity relative to them.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

answer.answer_text: No, at least one of your answers is not correct.
answer.response: $@NULL@$
0 m/s
(2 m/s, right)
(7 m/s, right)
(5 m/s, right)

page.title: Relative velocity of ships
page.contents:
Two ships are moving.  The SS Action moves with a velocity of

$$\vec{v}_A = 3 \hat{i} \, \textrm{m/s}$$

Meanwhile the HMS Bombastic moves with a velocity of

$$\vec{v}_B = - \hat{i} +3 \hat{j} \, \textrm{m/s}$$

Find the velocity of the Bombastic, relative to the Action.

answer.response: Yes.

No, you must have reversed the order of the vectors in the calculation and so you have found the velocity of the Action relative to the Bombastic rather than the velocity of the Bombastic relative to the Action.

That isn't a vector.  A velocity is a vector and you have been asked to find a velocity.  So this can't be correct.

You have found the relative speed...
No.  It looks like you added the two velocities.  That's not how you find a relative velocity.

page.title: Reflect on what you have learned
page.contents:
You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after the first half of the lesson.

Under what you wrote for the first half of the lesson write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. In a graph of x-component of velocity vs. time, what is the significance of the area under the curve for any time interval from some time, \( t_i \), to some later time, \( t_f \)?

You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: All reflections
page.contents:
This is only here so that if the Lesson navigation failed and you couldn't access one of the Reflective Writing pages you can view their content here.  Most of the time there should be no need for you to visit this page.

----------First Half-----------

Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1104 - Response to Unit 2 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper.  Don't put your name on it; I would rather mark "bllind".  Write a big heading saying "First Half".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. Can displacement be negative?  Can the x-component of displacement be negative?  If either or both of these can be negative then describe the circumstances under which it is negative.

You will add more to this sheet after one of the other lectures in this unit.  You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

------------End of Lesson-----------

2. page.title: which statement about x vs. t graph is correct (1)
page.contents:
Below is a graph showing the x-component of position vs. time for some object.

Which of the following statements is true?  (Only one of them is true)

answer.response: Yes, the tangent line to point 2 is not as steep as the line connecting 2 to 4.
No. The tangent line at 2 is not as steep as the line connecting 2 to 4. So the average velocity from 2 to 4 is larger than the instantaneous velocity at 2.
No. The line connecting 2 to 4 is steeper than the line connecting 1 to 3.
No. The tangent line at 4 is steeper than the tangent line at 2.

page.title: End of cluster 2-4
page.contents: End of cluster

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: find displacement - 2
page.contents:
A ball starts 4 m below a hoop as shown.  Someone has very conveniently left a big bold set of axes taped to the hoop (the origin is at the hoop).  The ball is thrown up through the hoop.  It rises to 2 m above the hoop and then falls back down.  On its way back through the hoop it gets stuck so that it remains in the hoop.  What is the y-component of displacement

of the ball?  (from the time it is thrown until it gets stuck)

answer.response:
Yes, it is just
$$\Delta y = y_f - y_i$$
No. That is the distance that the ball has travelled. Distance travelled is quite different from displacement. Watch the last few minutes of the lecture again if you don't understand the distinction.
No, that is its final position. Displacement is the change in position. It is only zero for an object that finishes in the same place that it started.
Oops! Did you do initial - final instead of final - initial?
No, that is the maximum displacement that the ball reaches, not its displacement from start to finish.

page.title: Cluster
page.contents: Cluster

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: get velocity from graph - 2
page.contents: Below is the x-component of position vs. time graph for some object.  What is the x-component of velocity of this object?

answer.response: Yes, it is just the slope of the line.

No, you seem to have used v = x/t instead of
$$v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}$$

answer.answer_text: We can't answer this. We need to know at what time, or between which times, we are finding the velocity.
answer.response: No. Notice that the x vs. t is a straight line. So this object is moving with constant velocity. We will get the same answer no matter what time, or between which two times, we find the velocity.
No. Did you do run/rise instead of rise/run in your calculation?
No. Did you do "initial - final" instead of "final - initial"?

page.title: Cluster
page.contents: Cluster

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: which statement about x vs. t graph is correct (2)
page.contents: The graph shows the x-component of position vs. time for two objects, A and B.  Which of the following statements is true? (Only one is true.)

answer.answer_text: During the time period shown, objects A and B are going at the same speed at only one instant in time.
answer.response: Yes. There is only one time (around the middle of the graph) when the tangent lines to the two curves have the same slope.

answer.answer_text: A goes faster than B for the whole time shown.
answer.response: No. Look at slopes. B has a constant slope (it is going at constant speed). But A reverses direction, so there is an instant when it stops entirely. Near this time it is certainly going slower than B.

answer.answer_text: During the time period shown there is no time when the two objects move at the same speed.
answer.response: No. There is one time when the slope of curve A matches the (constant) slope of B.

answer.answer_text: A and B are both moving at constant speed.
answer.response: No. B is moving at constant speed but A is not (its x vs. t graph is curved).

answer.answer_text: During the whole time period shown object A is speeding up.
answer.response: No. It stops at one point early in the motion (its slope is zero at that instant). Before that instant A is slowing down.

page.title: Choose correct displacement vector (picture)
page.contents:
Suppose some object moves from some location to another.  The diagram at right shows the initial and final locations.

Which of the options below the diagram shows the correct relationship between the initial position, final position, and displacement vectors?

answer.response: Yes.

No.  Notice that the displacement vector points in the wrong direction.  It should point down and slightly to the right (from initial location to final location), but in this choice the displacement points the opposite way.  Notice that the displacement doesn't point so that its head is where you would wind up if you follow r_i and r_f going from tail to head.  So this  is an incorrect picture of vector subtraction.

No.  Notice that the displacement vector points in the wrong direction.  It should point down and slightly to the right (from initial location to final location), but in this choice the displacement points the opposite way.  Also, you should be looking for a picture showing vector subtraction, which means that \(-\vec{r}_i\) should be in the picture.  But this picture has \(\vec{r}_i\), not \(-\vec{r}_i\).

No.  None of the vectors in this choice resemble any of the position or displacement vectors we should see from the diagram.  In the diagram the object moves down and slightly to the right.  So the displacement vector should point down and slightly right.  Directions matter.  Vectors have magnitude and direction.  So if the direction isn't correct the vector isn't correct.
